episodeTitle: Luffy Drowning! Zoro vs Octopus Hatchan!
episodeTitleJapanese: ルフィ水没！ゾロVSタコのはっちゃん
episodeTitleRomanized: Rufi Suibotsu! Zoro tai Tako no Hatchan
description: Zoro faces the six-sword wielding octopus fish-man Hatchan in an intense battle. Meanwhile, Luffy remains trapped underwater with concrete blocks, and Nojiko and Genzo work desperately to keep him alive. Sanji prepares to dive in to rescue Luffy, knowing he'll face Kuroobi in the water.

events.title: Genzo and Nojiko Attempt to Save Luffy
events.description: With Luffy trapped underwater with concrete blocks attached to his feet, Genzo and Nojiko secretly enter Arlong Park to rescue him. Genzo attempts to break the concrete while Nojiko keeps Luffy's head above water so he can breathe.
events.significance: Shows the villagers' courage and their willingness to help the Straw Hats despite years of living in fear under Arlong's rule. Demonstrates the growing trust between the crew and Cocoyasi Village residents.

quotes.text: We have to save him! The Straw Hats are fighting for our village!
quotes.speaker: Genzo
quotes.context: Genzo deciding to risk his life to save Luffy

events.title: Zoro vs Hatchan Battle Begins
events.description: Zoro engages in battle with Hatchan, the six-sword wielding octopus fish-man. Despite still recovering from his wounds from Mihawk, Zoro accepts the challenge to prevent Hatchan from interfering with the rescue efforts.
events.significance: First major one-on-one fight for Zoro in the Arlong Park arc, testing his resolve and strength while still injured. Shows Zoro's determination to protect his crew even when not at full strength.

quotes.text: Six swords? That's nothing compared to my three-sword style!
quotes.speaker: Zoro
quotes.context: Zoro's confidence despite being outnumbered in weapons

events.title: Hatchan Demonstrates Six Sword Style
events.description: Hatchan showcases his unique Six Sword Style (Rokutoryu) fighting technique, wielding six swords simultaneously with his octopus tentacles. He explains his pride in having more swords than any regular swordsman.
events.significance: Introduces a unique fighting style that challenges the traditional notion that more weapons equal more power, setting up Zoro's counter-argument about quality over quantity.

quotes.text: I'm Hatchan the octopus! I wield six swords with my six arms!
quotes.speaker: Hatchan
quotes.context: Hatchan boasting about his fighting style

events.title: Zoro Borrows Additional Swords
events.description: Recognizing that his current swords might not be enough, Zoro borrows two additional swords from defeated Arlong Pirates members to match Hatchan's six-sword style, demonstrating adaptability in combat.
events.significance: Shows Zoro's pragmatism and willingness to adapt his fighting style to match his opponent, though he ultimately proves that sword quantity isn't what matters most.

events.title: Zoro Debuts Tatsu Maki (Dragon Twister)
events.description: Zoro unleashes his new technique, Tatsu Maki (Dragon Twister), spinning with his swords to create a dragon-like tornado that slashes and blows away targets. The technique destroys all six of Hatchan's swords and sends him flying into the air.
events.significance: First appearance of one of Zoro's signature Three Sword Style techniques. Demonstrates Zoro's growth as a swordsman and establishes that skill and technique matter more than the number of weapons. This technique becomes a staple of Zoro's fighting repertoire throughout the series.

quotes.speaker: Zoro
quotes.context: Zoro announcing his new technique as he defeats Hatchan

events.title: Zoro Defeats Hatchan
events.description: With Tatsu Maki, Zoro completely defeats Hatchan, breaking all of his swords and launching him into the air. Hatchan crashes down defeated, unable to continue fighting.
events.significance: Marks Zoro's first victory in the Arlong Park battles, proving that despite his injuries from Mihawk, he can still defeat powerful opponents. Establishes the theme that quality and skill triumph over quantity.

quotes.text: It's not about how many swords you have... it's about how you use them!
quotes.speaker: Zoro
quotes.context: Zoro's philosophy on swordsmanship after defeating Hatchan

events.title: Sanji Dives to Rescue Luffy
events.description: Seeing that Genzo and Nojiko cannot free Luffy on their own, Sanji makes the critical decision to dive into the water to save his captain, fully aware that Kuroobi will have a significant advantage in the underwater environment.
events.significance: Demonstrates Sanji's loyalty and willingness to sacrifice his advantageous position to save a crewmate. Shows the crew's bond and their priority on protecting each other above winning individual battles.

quotes.speaker: Sanji
quotes.context: Sanji diving into the water to rescue Luffy despite the danger

events.title: Sanji vs Kuroobi Underwater Battle Begins
events.description: As Sanji attempts to free Luffy from the concrete blocks underwater, Kuroobi intercepts him. The fish-man attacks Sanji using his superior underwater abilities and Fish-Man Karate, putting the cook at a severe disadvantage.
events.significance: Sets up one of the most challenging battles for Sanji in the arc, where he must fight in an environment completely favorable to his opponent while simultaneously trying to save Luffy. Tests Sanji's resourcefulness and determination.

quotes.text: In the water, no human can defeat a fish-man!
quotes.speaker: Kuroobi
quotes.context: Kuroobi's confidence in his underwater advantage

events.title: Kuroobi Demonstrates Fish-Man Karate
events.description: Kuroobi showcases his Fish-Man Karate abilities underwater, explaining that he is a level 40 practitioner. He uses powerful water-based attacks that are exponentially more effective in his natural aquatic environment.
events.significance: Introduces Fish-Man Karate as a formidable martial art and establishes the biological advantages fish-men have underwater. This fighting style becomes important in later arcs of the series.

quotes.text: I am a level 40 Fish-Man Karate practitioner! In the water, I'm invincible!
quotes.speaker: Kuroobi
quotes.context: Kuroobi explaining his martial arts prowess

events.title: Chew Pursues Usopp
events.description: The fish-man Chew chases Usopp through the outskirts of Arlong Park and the surrounding area. Usopp uses his knowledge of the terrain and his cunning to evade Chew's water-based attacks.
events.significance: Continues Usopp's storyline in the arc, showing his resourcefulness when facing a physically superior opponent. Sets up his eventual confrontation with Chew.

events.title: Nami Decides to Rejoin the Battle
events.description: After bandaging her wounds at her house, Nami makes the decision to return to Arlong Park and rejoin her crewmates in battle. Despite her injuries and emotional trauma, she chooses to fight alongside the Straw Hats.
events.significance: Marks Nami's full commitment to the crew and her decision to fight for her freedom and village. Shows her character growth from someone who tried to handle everything alone to someone who accepts help and fights alongside friends.

quotes.text: I can't just sit here while they're fighting for me!
quotes.speaker: Nami
quotes.context: Nami's determination to rejoin the battle

quotes.speaker: Zoro
quotes.context: Zoro unleashing his Dragon Twister technique to defeat Hatchan

quotes.text: It's not about how many swords you have... it's about how you use them!
quotes.speaker: Zoro
quotes.context: Zoro's philosophy after defeating the six-sword wielding Hatchan

quotes.text: In the water, no human can defeat a fish-man!
quotes.speaker: Kuroobi
quotes.context: Kuroobi's overconfidence in his underwater advantage

quotes.speaker: Sanji
quotes.context: Sanji diving to rescue Luffy despite the danger

themes.description: Zoro's battle with Hatchan emphasizes that skill and technique are more important than sheer numbers. Despite Hatchan wielding six swords, Zoro's superior swordsmanship with his three-sword style proves victorious.
themes.symbolism: The destruction of all six of Hatchan's swords by Zoro's three represents that mastery and dedication to one's craft outweigh superficial advantages.

themes.description: Both the villagers (Genzo and Nojiko) and the crew members (Sanji) demonstrate willingness to sacrifice their safety for others. Sanji gives up his advantageous position to save Luffy, while the villagers risk Arlong's wrath to help.
themes.symbolism: The underwater setting represents the depths people will go to for those they care about, even when it means entering unfavorable or dangerous situations.

themes.description: The episode reinforces that the Straw Hats and the villagers are fighting together. No one faces their challenges in isolation - there's always someone willing to help.
themes.symbolism: Luffy being kept alive by multiple people working together (Genzo, Nojiko, and then Sanji) symbolizes the power of collective effort over individual strength.

characterSpotlights.development: Zoro proves that despite his severe injuries from Mihawk, his skill and determination make him a formidable warrior. He debuts a new technique and demonstrates growth in his fighting abilities.
keyActions: Borrows additional swords to match Hatchan
Proves quality over quantity in swordsmanship
quotes: It's not about how many swords you have... it's about how you use them!

characterSpotlights.development: Sanji demonstrates his selflessness by abandoning his advantageous position to save Luffy, knowing he'll face Kuroobi at a severe disadvantage underwater.
keyActions: Decides to dive into water to save Luffy
Faces Kuroobi underwater despite the disadvantage
Prioritizes crew safety over personal victory

characterSpotlights.development: Genzo shows courage by actively helping the Straw Hats despite years of living in fear under Arlong's rule, marking his transition from passive victim to active helper.
keyActions: Sneaks into Arlong Park to save Luffy
Risks his life for the crew fighting for his village

characterSpotlights.development: Nojiko demonstrates bravery similar to Genzo, actively participating in the rescue mission and showing her support for Nami and the crew.
keyActions: Helps keep Luffy's head above water
Works with Genzo to save Luffy
Actively supports the Straw Hats' fight

mangaDifferences.difference: In the manga, Zoro broke Hatchan's swords with Oni Giri first before finishing with Tatsu Maki. In the anime, Zoro defeats Hatchan using only Tatsu Maki.

trivia.fact: This episode marks the first appearance of Zoro's Tatsu Maki (Dragon Twister) technique, which becomes one of his signature moves throughout the series.

sources.title: Three Sword Style - One Piece Wiki

trivia.fact: The 4Kids English dub combined this episode with part of Episode 40 to create their Episode 37, significantly altering the pacing.
This episode adapts parts of three manga chapters: Chapter 84 (pages 2-19), Chapter 85 (pages 2-19), and Chapter 86 (pages 2-6).
The name 'Tatsu Maki' (龍巻き) is a play on words - it means 'tornado' in Japanese but also references the dragon (龍/tatsu) imagery associated with the technique.
Hatchan is voiced by Toshiyuki Morikawa in Japanese, who is also known for voicing Sephiroth in Final Fantasy VII.
